questions.question: Which is the brightest star in the night sky, also known as the 'Dog Star'?
questions.lore: Sirius is part of the constellation Canis Major (The Great Dog). Its name holds significance for the wizard Sirius Black, whose Animagus form is a large black dog.

questions.question: The moons of which planet are known to be particularly useful in potion-making?
questions.lore: The dust from the moons of Mars, Phobos and Deimos, is said to have magical properties that can enhance the effects of certain brews when harvested correctly.

questions.question: From which tower at Hogwarts are Astronomy lessons traditionally held?
questions.lore: The Astronomy Tower is the tallest tower at Hogwarts, offering the best, unobstructed view of the night sky for star-charting and practical exams.

questions.question: The constellation 'Draco' is depicted as what creature?
questions.lore: The Draco constellation is one of the largest in the northern sky. It is also the source of the name for the Malfoy family scion, Draco.

questions.question: What is a 'Crescent Moon'?
options: A full moon partially obscured by clouds
The phase of the moon when it is less than half full
The moon during a lunar eclipse
A moon that is shaped like a banana
questions.lore: The crescent phase occurs just after the new moon and just before the old moon. Some magical plants, like Fluxweed, must be harvested during specific lunar phases.

questions.question: The planet Venus is often referred to as the:
questions.lore: Because of its brightness and visibility just before sunrise or just after sunset, Venus holds a special place in both Muggle and wizarding astronomy.

questions.question: What is the primary tool used by students for their practical Astronomy exams?
questions.lore: Students are required to own a telescope for charting the stars. For the O.W.L. exam, they must fill in a blank star chart based on their observations.

questions.question: A lunar eclipse occurs when which celestial body passes directly behind the Earth?
questions.lore: During a total lunar eclipse, the Earth completely blocks direct sunlight from reaching the Moon, often giving it a reddish hue known as a 'blood moon'.

questions.question: The constellation 'Orion' is easily identifiable by what feature?
options: A bright, red star at its shoulder
A belt of three bright stars
Its proximity to the North Star
questions.lore: Orion's Belt is one of the most recognizable asterisms in the night sky. The red supergiant, Betelgeuse, forms one of Orion's shoulders.

questions.question: Which of Jupiter's moons is known for its many active volcanoes?
questions.lore: The constant volcanic activity on Io makes its surface a chaotic landscape of sulfur deposits, and its magical energy is considered highly unstable.

questions.question: What is the term for a star that suddenly increases greatly in brightness, then slowly fades back to its original state?
questions.lore: A nova is a cataclysmic nuclear explosion on a white dwarf star. A supernova, by contrast, is a much larger explosion that results in the star's destruction.

questions.question: The North Star, Polaris, is useful for navigation because:
options: It is the brightest star in the sky
It remains in a fixed position in the sky
It changes colour throughout the night
It is only visible in winter
questions.lore: Polaris is located almost directly above the Earth's North Pole, so it appears stationary while other stars revolve around it, making it a reliable celestial marker.

questions.question: What is a nebula?
options: A giant cloud of dust and gas in space
A cluster of very old stars
A galaxy in its early stages of formation
The remnant of an exploded star
questions.lore: Nebulae are often called 'stellar nurseries' because they are the regions where new stars are born from collapsing clouds of gas and dust.

questions.question: The 'Summer Triangle' is an astronomical asterism formed by which three bright stars?
questions.lore: This prominent asterism is visible in the summer night sky of the Northern Hemisphere, with each star being the brightest in its own constellation.

questions.question: What is the difference between a meteor and a meteorite?
options: A meteor burns up in the atmosphere, a meteorite lands on Earth
A meteorite is larger than a meteor
Meteors are made of ice, meteorites are made of rock
questions.lore: A meteoroid is the object in space. It becomes a meteor (or shooting star) when it enters the atmosphere, and a meteorite if any part of it survives the journey to the ground.

questions.question: Which constellation represents a centaur, a creature well-versed in astronomy?
questions.lore: Both Sagittarius and Centaurus depict centaurs. The centaur Firenze, who taught at Hogwarts, was a master of divination through stargazing.

questions.question: The movement of which planet is said to have the greatest influence on divination?
questions.lore: In classical astrology, Saturn is considered the great 'teacher' and its position is believed to heavily influence long-term destiny and major life events.

questions.question: An 'occultation' occurs when:
options: A planet aligns with a star
An object is hidden by another object passing in front of it
questions.lore: A common example is when the Moon passes in front of a distant star or planet, temporarily blocking it from view.

questions.question: The rings of Saturn are primarily composed of what?
questions.lore: The countless particles that form Saturn's rings range in size from tiny specks of dust to objects as large as a mountain.

questions.question: What does the term 'syzygy' refer to in astronomy?
options: The straight-line configuration of three celestial bodies
The wobble of a planet on its axis
questions.lore: A common syzygy involves the Sun, Earth, and either the Moon or a planet. Solar and lunar eclipses are types of syzygy.

questions.question: The constellation 'Lyra' is associated with what musical instrument?
questions.lore: Lyra represents the lyre of Orpheus from Greek mythology. Its brightest star is Vega.

questions.question: What is the 'zodiac'?
options: A belt of stars in the sky where all constellations are located
A specific group of 12 powerful stars
The area of the sky through which the Sun, Moon, and planets appear to pass
questions.lore: The zodiacal constellations are those that lie along the apparent path of the Sun, and they are central to both astronomy and astrology.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT a phase of the Moon?
questions.lore: The phases of the moon are New, Waxing Crescent, First Quarter, Waxing Gibbous, Full, Waning Gibbous, Third Quarter, and Waning Crescent. 'Shadow Moon' is not a standard term.

questions.question: The 'Sea of Tranquility' (Mare Tranquillitatis) is a famous location on what celestial body?
questions.lore: This lunar mare is most famous for being the landing site of the first Muggles on the Moon in 1969, an event that caused considerable discussion at the Ministry.

questions.question: Why is it often difficult to observe Mercury?
options: It is obscured by dust clouds
It is very close to the Sun
questions.lore: Because of its proximity to the Sun, Mercury is often lost in the Sun's glare and is only visible for short periods during twilight.
